posts.cooked:
Hey there folks, now that my team’s season is done for the year, I want to perform an autopsy on our our robot to examine the strengths and failures, and learn how we can avoid repeating the mistakes we made this year.

What does this mean? I want us to take apart everything we built and lay it out on the floor like the FAA does with a crashed plane. Here’s what I’m hoping to get out of it:

document each step of disassembly, noting which places are difficult to reach due to design and any discrepancies between left side/ right side and front/ back.

document the use of countersunk bolts where there shouldn’t be, regular nuts instead of lock nuts, etc.

document where Max tube was installed backwards so the cut lines don’t line up.

document where wires are too tight or too long and not properly secured.

document any damaged pieces from competition collisions.

document any crookedness and the source of it (mis drilled holes, mismatched parts, etc.)

This was a rebuilding year for our team- we only had one senior this year, and he was only part-time. A lot of mistakes were made during design and fabrication, but the team learned a lot from the experience. This is my fifth year as a mentor for my son’s team (ftc+frc), and while it was hard to let them fail when they ignored our advice, it was amazing to see them learn and mature from the process.

Has anyone else done this? Do you have any tips or suggestions on a protocol to use?

posts.name: ToddF
posts.cooked: I don’t know that I have any tips for you, but this exercise will be one of the most valuable learning experiences you will have to learn what works and what doesn’t in an FRC robot.

posts.name: Libby Kamen
posts.cooked:
We don’t do this in such a detailed robot way, (simply because we hadn’t thought of it! We might try this in the future) … but in the vein of ‘valuable learning experiences’, 1923 at the end of each event (and concluding each season) does an exercise called “Good, Bad, Ugly.”

We review absolutely anything about our team’s execution - things within our control, of course - and then categorize it into one of the three spaces.

Good = This was awesome, let’s keep doing it. This can be things like, “Spirit was super high! Keep it up!” or, “Scouting’s data collection was exceptionally detailed”. Basically, what lightning do we want to bottle for next event?

Bad = Not interested in repeating, let’s document an improvement process. “We missed some bolt/hardware options on our packing list, let’s make sure for next event we physically print out the packing list and check things off as they go in.”

Ugly = This can never, ever happen again, no excuses. “We forgot our blue bumpers for IRI. Let’s make sure during the packing process, at LEAST three people verify we have both colors with us.” Or sometimes, this is a severe behavioral thing - someone was talking through opening ceremonies, or on their phone when they should have been scouting.

Just offering up another way to ‘look back’ that may not be as robot-specific.

link_counts.title: 50 Fun Ways to Lose a Match

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Lead Mentor | Team 1923: The MidKnight Inventors

posts.custom_user_title: Lead Mentor | Team 1923: The MidKnight Inventors

posts.name: Ryan Coleman
posts.cooked:
This is a great idea, there’s also a variant called “Start, Stop, Continue” which (I think) is pretty self explanatory in intent - one thing I like about having a ‘start’ option is it makes space for ideas that are net new and maybe not directly (or obviously) linked to a shortcoming or issue in the past season.

(But that idea can be worked into G/B/U as well just in how the questions are setup)

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
We use Thorns, Roses and Buds (I got this from my boyscout troop and carried it over to our team). After each event we hold a retro meeting to discuss what we need to do differently for the next event or if it’s the last event of the season we plan out what to do for offseason and summer training. This includes improving the existing robot, planning for off-season events, and training younger members before the seniors vanish in a puff of smoke.

The thorns are the bad, roses are good and buds are things that we can start doing now to have more roses and less thorns the next time.

Depending on how the event went you may have to come up with some stretches for the roses sometimes. The good part of it is every event had positive things happen you can point to and help boost morale.

This can be applied to robot specifics too or really any part of the team

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
We similarly do good-bad-ugly. Start/Stop/Continue is solid as well - subtly different depending on whether new ideas are in scope for the discussion or not. Depending on the people, discussing next steps will quickly derail the discussion about the event itself.

It also prompts the question, “but have you seen the movie?”. I’ve yet to find a student who saw it before it was recommended.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: ARGH!  I wish my kids had seen this before they stripped the robot to put on an Aluminum belly pan!!!

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: Related to this - my team does a “Plus / Delta” for each branch at the end of each season. “Plus” refers to things we did great this season and should continue to do, “Delta” refers to changes we should make next year, which includes both new ideas and mistakes we want to not make again. These meetings are recorded on google docs that are posted on our team slack, and all prospective executive members have to either attend all the meetings in person or read all the documents to run for a leadership position.

posts.name: Kasper
posts.cooked: We also use Thorns, Roses, And Buds! We do it as a whole team and break it into subteams if needed later on

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
The link between problems and the best solutions is root cause analysis. There are plenty of web sites with 5 to 10 “bullet points” to give you ideas on why and how to conduct these analyses. You can treat both the root cause and proximate cause to help your next build.

Root cause analysis (RCA) is the process of discovering the root causes of problems in order to identify appropriate solutions .

morgajel:

hard to let them fail when they ignored our advice

and it’s hard to know when to let them fail because they ignore our advice or expressed better “It’s hard for a mentor to know how hard to push to get their way.”

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
I like to look at robot performance under a couple of lenses.

(1) If we executed a match perfectly what would be our peak performance, then (comparing with higher performing robots) what design choices did we make that limited our best possible performance?  (and were these things within the capabilities or our team?)

(2) for each of our matches, a “failure mode analysis” – what things happened that kept us from reaching our peak? some possibilities:

sub-optimal match strategy,

agreeing to an alliance role not well suited to us,

failures in the pre-match checklist (missing items or items missed),

failures in on-field pre-match robot prep (eg lined up wrong)

code failures (typically in auton),

drive team errors (strategic or tactical),

robot failures. – own goals (like when we drove over our own sparkmaxes), – caused by other robots

In my mind, it seems like you are mostly paying attention to just the last item (which is definitely important, but not everything)

posts.name: Camden Clear
posts.cooked: I love this! My troop uses it too, we learned it from our ranger out in Philmont.

posts.name: Random Guy
posts.cooked: OK how many of us do both FRC and Scouting?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: A decent number (student leadership and groups based around learning life skills seems to draw the same people). On our team I’m an Eagle Scout (as of 2013) and head coach. I’ve had 8 or 9 scouts as part of the team. 4 went on to get their Eagle as well.

posts.name: coderkevin
posts.cooked: After each competition our team goes through a Root Cause Analysis on any failures or issues we had. We ask the “5 whys” and try to come up with a solution at each level, that way we cover the issue in the future in multiple ways.

posts.name: Blake Bourque
posts.cooked:
Don’t forget about the offseason! We work to keep our robots running through the fall so new team members can experience competitions and try out for drive team.

Lean and Agile tell us that we need to shorten feedback loops. How can you learn about all the things above sooner in a non destructive way?

Huge shout out to the teams that do retrospectives after each event. This is a great time to capture lessons learned and also activities/behaviors/designs that work well to ensure those continue.

Our team works to constantly make small changes and test, always looking for improvements.

I like this- I’m used to start/stop/continue or +/-/Delta, but I think there’s a place for explicitly calling out the Ugly. We had a couple of issues that are worth calling out explicitly so everyone is on the lookout next year.

I’m looking for a step beyond RCA (I work in IT so I’m familair). I want them to question their initial design decisions and see if there’s a better way, not just look at failures (of which we had plenty).

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

“It’s hard for a mentor to know how hard to push to get their way.”

I can’t tell if this is a dig at me for being an overzealous mentor. One of our team’s mentorship rules is that it’s the student’s bot, not ours- they will win and lose by their own choices.

At the beginning of the year, we asked the students for their priority this year- learning, or winning. Almost to a person, they chose learning.

We will offer them advice when they ask, and even offer unsolicited advice when they are making (in our opinion) a mistake, but we avoid intervening unless they’re doing something dangerous (or extremely costly).

We have tools at our disposal to help them think; e.g. asking probing and/or leading questions, for example. We’ll often ask them to explain their rationale to another student that we expect will see the issue.

The downside to this method is:

we’ll never be able to compete with “parentbots” which are common in our area.

When students ignore input from both the other students and the mentors, it sets up the whole team for failure.

That second point bit us this year because we didn’t have any full-time seniors on our team, and the juniors weren’t comfortable stepping up and telling people no.

It cost us. Our first competition we came in 39th of 42. BUT… the team learned and grew like crazy because of it.  Conflict-averse juniors will be decisive leaders their senior year. Sophomores who made mistakes learned from their hubris and know that individuals can’t win a team game. Freshmen learned to speak up when they see bad ideas and call people out (constructively, of course).

It was painful to watch, but the team is much better for it.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
morgajel:

better way

That’s a somewhat broad area and I’d highlight and pursue one thing that students usually don’t even think about - mistake-proofing. They are optimistic. Nothing will go wrong!

If you documented your early designs that were rejected, you could review to see if you missed an opportunity.

There are plenty of CD threads about adult involvement. I was alluding to my concern that one student’s lack could sabotage the team’s otherwise higher accomplishments. Adult intervention could save the day. Maybe your highly developed culture mitigates this with students being specifically able to handle this.

posts.name: coderkevin
posts.cooked:
morgajel:

When students ignore input from both the other students and the mentors, it sets up the whole team for failure.

Respectfully, this is where I would draw the line as a mentor. Mistakes are constructive learning tools, yes, but catastrophic design problems stop the learning at that point and don’t allow it to go any further. It’s not very inspiring to the rest of the students to allow one student’s hubris to ruin the season for everyone on the team. Think of how many other opportunities the team may have missed out on because they couldn’t progress past this one critical failure mode.
